Award.AwardTitle: Symposium (workshop) on the Application of Mechanics to Geophysics: San Diego, CA, June 2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
This travel grant supports students and early career researchers to participate in an interdisciplinary workshop. The meeting will stimulate discussion between the geophysics and mechanics/engineering communities. They will identify outstanding problems and advance the state-of-the-art in mechanical models for geophysical problems. Scientific areas for collaboration include rock mechanics, seismology, physical volcanology and fracture mechanics. Dealing with big data and more realistic models will be a focus of the effort. The meeting will take place at the University of California, San Diego.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes for NSF award # 1903904: "Symposium on the Application of Mechanics to Geophysics",

UCSD, June 25-26, 2019

organized by Xanthippi Markenscoff and Yuri Fialko

 

Project outcomes: The Symposium http://maeresearch.ucsd.edu/markenscoff/nsf/

was held on June 25-26, 2019 at UCSD, La Jolla, CA and was co-organized by Yuri Fialko, Scripps Institute of Oceanography, UCSD, and Xanthippi Markenscoff, Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, UCSD. In addition to NSF it was co-funded by the Green Foundation at UCSD. The Symposium included fourteen forty minutes talks with discussion and 14 poster presentations by graduate students and postdocs from across the country.

The symposium brought together leading members of the geophysics and mechanics communities and enhanced strong interactions with focus on adapting the current state- of-the-art mechanics models for interpreting and understanding the geophysical phenomena.  Outstanding problems were identified and the pathways for making advances in understanding and interpreting the geophysical phenomena. The topics included state interaction of fluids with solids (linking fluid flow and geomechanics to mitigate injection-induced seismicity), effects of friction at broad scales on fault dynamics, effects of viscosity and creep, in particular in creating fault instabilities, the mechanics of deep earthquakes as dynamic phase transformations and the mechanics of caldera eruption, and the methodologies involved analysis, modeling, computations including machine learning, and experiments. The exchanges are likely to have long-lasting impacts on both mechanics and geophysics, and the deeper understanding of the natural phenomena such as earthquakes and volcanoes may ultimately improve hazard mitigation and thus be of a direct benefit to the society. The workshop promoted the participation of early career scientists who benefited from the in-depth talks and discussions of their work by the senior participants.
